Award.AwardTitle: 2018 Plant Cell Dynamics (PCD) Meeting; May 29-June 1, 2018; University of Wisconsin-Madison

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Uncovering fundamental mechanisms of organelle and cell dynamics is required for a comprehensive model of plant growth and development as well as for understanding how plants adapt to their environment. Such knowledge is critical for fundamental advances in basic plant cell biology and promoting future applications to agriculture. The 2018 Plant Cell Dynamics conference, to be held May 29-June 1, 2018 at the University of Wisconsin, Madison campus will focus on providing opportunities for plant cell biologists to learn quantitative approaches to analyze cellular dynamics and function, including live cell imaging and computational tools. It will also provide a venue for students, postdoctoral scientists, and new investigators to interact with established leaders in the field of plant cell biology, thus providing positive impacts on career development for students and trainees at all levels. By encouraging and supporting attendance of trainees from underrepresented groups, the conference will broaden participation in this developing field, which employs techniques of quantitative, predictive, and theory-driven biology, and encourages multidisciplinary approaches.

The conference will include keynote talks from experts in the field of plant cell biology on methodology appropriate for quantitative studies that probe how plant cells integrate metabolism, cytoskeletal organization, and vesicle trafficking in overall cellular function. In addition, there will be opportunities for oral and poster presentations by trainees and participation in hands-on workshops on sample preparation, long-term time-lapse imaging, and image processing.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award provided fellowships that increased the participation of students and underrepresented groups in the 2018 meeting entitled ?Midwest Plant Cell Dynamics?. The meeting exposed all participants to cutting edge plant cell biology and the use of quantitative image analyses and computational tools to discover mechanisms underlying cellular processes in plants. The knowledge gained from this research will help drive the development of improved crops of agronomic importance. The oral presentation from keynote speaker Dr. Michael Blatt (Glasgow University, Scotland) demonstrated the utility and importance of quantitative analysis of cellular and membrane dynamicsto understand cellular growth control. Similarly, in the second keynote address, Dr. Adrienne Roeder (Cornell University) emphasized the use of high-resolution spatial analyses coupled to genetics to help understand regulatory mechanisms of plant tissue patterning in sepals.Nearly all meeting attendees participated in the workshops. The meeting also included oral presentations from 37 different labs. Presentations were given almost exclusively by graduate students and post-docs, providing an important training opportunity. Poster sessions were also very successful, providing excellent interactions among students, post-docs, and PIs. The NSF fellowships enabled a broad group of scientists to attend the meeting and a post-meeting survey indicated that approximately 25% of the attendees were able to present at the meeting because of the NSF fellowship support. Post-meeting survey results from the 7 years that the meeting has been running also show that between 70-80% of respondents indicate the availability of such NSF support remains an important factor in their research group?s ability to decide on whether they can attend the meeting each year.
